name: Cana of Galilee
shortDescription: Galilean village where Jesus performed his first miracle (water to wine) and birthplace of the apostle Nathanael/Bartholomew
fullDescription: Cana of Galilee holds a unique place in Christian tradition as the site of Jesus's first public miracle - the transformation of water into wine at a wedding feast (John 2:1-11). This 'beginning of signs' manifested his glory and led his disciples to believe in him. The village is also identified as the hometown of Nathanael (Bartholomew), the skeptic apostle whom Jesus called 'an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile.' The connection between Cana and Nathanael is explicitly stated in John 21:2. Jesus also healed a royal official's son from Cana (John 4:46-54), making this his second Galilean sign. The site's identification remains debated among scholars, with Kafr Kanna (traditional) and Khirbet Qana (archaeological) as primary candidates. The wedding miracle symbolizes the transformation of Jewish purification rituals (the water jars) into the new wine of the Messianic age, while Nathanael's origin from this village connects the first miracle to the calling of the first disciples.

modernIdentification.name: Kafr Kanna
modernIdentification.description: Christian tradition since Byzantine era; contains wedding church

metaphysicalProperties.significance: Site of first manifestation of divine glory

inhabitants.name: Nathanael (Bartholomew)
inhabitants.description: Apostle born in Cana, called 'Israelite without guile'

events.name: Wedding at Cana (c. 27 CE)
events.description: Jesus's first miracle: transforming water in purification jars into excellent wine, 'the beginning of signs' that manifested his glory

events.name: Healing of Royal Official's Son (c. 28 CE)
events.description: Jesus healed the son of a royal official from Capernaum while remaining in Cana - his second Galilean sign, demonstrating power over distance

events.name: Calling of Nathanael (c. 27 CE)
events.description: Philip brought Nathanael of Cana to Jesus, who identified him as 'an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile'

mythologyContexts.usage: Site of Jesus's first miracle; birthplace of apostle Nathanael; pilgrimage destination

textReferences.context: Wedding miracle - water to wine, 'beginning of signs'
Healing of royal official's son from Cana
Nathanael identified as 'of Cana in Galilee'

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Cana represents the transformation of the old covenant into the new. The six stone water jars for Jewish purification (holding 20-30 gallons each) being filled with superior wine symbolizes Jesus fulfilling and surpassing the Law. The 'best wine saved for last' indicates the Messianic age surpassing all that came before. Mary's presence and intercession foreshadows her role in Christian devotion.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Cana became an important pilgrimage site, particularly for couples seeking blessing on their marriages. The Wedding Church in Kafr Kanna commemorates the miracle. The transformation narrative has influenced Christian understanding of sacraments, particularly the Eucharist as wine becoming Christ's blood.

mythologyContexts.usage: First-century Galilean village in the context of Second Temple Judaism
mythologyContexts.symbolism: The stone water jars represent Jewish purity laws. Their transformation suggests the relationship between Torah observance and messianic fulfillment in Jewish-Christian thought.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Nathanael's origin from Cana and his role as 'true Israelite' connects Jewish identity with recognition of Jesus as Messiah. His initial skepticism ('Can anything good come from Nazareth?') reflects Galilean village rivalries.
